body: Yup, this will be fixed by tomorrow. Psalm just needs to introspect on the callables.

issue.title: sort functions considered impure?

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
Hi,

In 690209d8e5d432938e2099c8b118872404e15ff1 usort() and uasort() have lost the `@psalm-pure` annotations.

Was it an expected change?

https://psalm.dev/r/fca3adb346

body: Is this really fixed? I'm having the same issue: https://psalm.dev/r/aa2b6f809d

It is. Purity of `array_map()/array_filter()` now depends on whether the callable they receive is pure. You may want to declare that you only accept pure callables by prefixing `Closure` with `pure-`: https://psalm.dev/r/4f237c3360
Seems this issue is still present when using array syntax for callables https://psalm.dev/r/db993dc30e

issue.title: array_map with mutation-free callable-array considered impure

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
Seems this issue is still present when using array syntax for callables https://psalm.dev/r/db993dc30e

_Originally posted by @yevsid in https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/issues/2112#issuecomment-1216195063_

Seems the issue has to do with `@psalm-mutation-free` vs `@psalm-pure`: https://psalm.dev/r/79d53f6cd5
